l.1 plateam | l.5 plateam

painted letters, simple in style without serifs and not perfectly following a horizontal line. Alpha has straight bar; theta is circular with a central point; M is very broad, all strokes diagonal, the mid-point not fully down to the lower line; sigma is lunate.
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana

Vento, 2000, Le stele dipinte di Lilibeo

1Μαρία ἥρυς
2ἀγαθά

Regular and neat letters without serifs. Alpha with both straight and broken bar, beta with closed loops (upper slightly smaller), Mu has full length slanting strokes; omicron full size; sigma has horizontal top and bottom; rhomboid omega.

2nd or 1st century BCE (as late as early Augustan acc. to Wilson and Manni Piraino; but Manni Piraino also suggests 2nd century BCE). The form of the letters surely suggests an earlier date in this range.
Manni Piraino, 1963, Due Iscrizioni inedite di Marsala
Manni Piraino ap. Di Stefano, 1984, Lilibeo. Testimonianze archeologiche dal IV sec a.C. al V sec. d.C.
Di Stefano, 2006, Lilibeo: contributo alla rilettura dell'insula I
Brugnone, 2021, Parlare greco a Lilibeo: la documentazione epigrafica tra II e I sec. a.C.

1šmgn   ←
A tessera hospitalis recording xenia between Imulch and Lyson
Four lines of Greek letters, with a consistent left margin, starting at the top of the rear (smooth) side of the tessera, with small vacat below.

Small, slightly irregular letters without serifs. Lunate epsilon, sigma and omega; mu formed by four, equal slanting strokes; omicron generally slightly smaller than other letters; beta is closed, but with separated loops; rho is closed; xsi in form of a Z with horizontal cross bar; kappa has short equal length arms.
2nd century BCE, or possibly 1st century BCE (the letter forms look more plausibly second than 1st century)
Paciaudi, 1751, Diatribe qua Graeci anaglyphi interpretatio traditur

Text is painted (red) in the upper part of the field on three lines (first line to left, lines 2-3 centred), above figure.
Elegant letters with simple serifs. Straight barred alpha; sigma with horizontal top and bottom strokes; rhomboid omega (open).
later second or earlier first century BCE

1Νικασίων
2Ἀριστίωνος
3χαῖρε
Remains of three lines are preserved, with uneven right margin and one letter vacat at end.

Plainly cut letters without serifs. Omicron slightly smaller and raised; omega open with short horizontal tails; sigma with full length strokes, parallel top and bottom; epsilon with shorter middle bar.
first century BCE or first century CE
Brugnone, 2016, Incontri di culture nelle epigrafi greche di Lilibeo

Fragment of a basin with inscribed rim
remains of five letters with a vacat following, filling the space on the rim.
Plainly cut letters with very basic terminal point serifs. Straight bar alpha.
Imperial period (i.e. first three centuries CE)
fragment of a basin with inscribed rim
1[---]τηρία
Remains of a single line of Latin letters filling the rim, with a vacat preceding.
Deep v-cut letters without serifs and quite a broad module.
1[---] (vac.) adducendam [---]

Neatly painted square letters with short serifs, painted in the style of stone cut letters. Alpha is broad with straight bar; Epsilon has equal length horizontal strokes; theta is ovoid with a full horizontal bar; kappa has arms that are not quite ful length; mu has vertical first and last, with middle strokes nearly reaching down to the line; pi has equal length verticals; sigma is four-bar, of equal length, top and bottom strokes horizontal.

1Ἀχιλλεὺς Προθύμου
2χαῖρε καὶ κατὰ
3χθονός
Four lines of Greek text, engraved in stucco and painted in red, across the full width of the rectangular block, with a vacat below.
Suggested to date to the later 3rd or earlier 2nd century BCE

Honorific inscription recording the colonia of Agrigentum
Three lines of Latin text, centred on the surviving stone which is regularly cut but re-used
Letters are relatively tall, with marked serifs and an ornate interpunct on line 1. P is open with extended foot at base; R is closed; G is formed by single curved stroke
